segments.title: GTP Proteins and the Actin Cytoskeleton
segments.text: Small monomeric GTP proteins such as **Rho, Rac, and Cdc42** are important for regulating changes in the cell's **actin cytoskeleton**. The cytoskeleton is heavily involved in **cell movement, division, and shape**, enabling cell migration and facilitating **cell-cell communication**. These small monomeric proteins function as **molecular switches** for these processes.

segments.question: What role do GTP proteins such as Rho, Rac, and Cdc42 play in the actin cytoskeleton?

answers.correct_answer: They regulate changes in the actin cytoskeleton
wrong_answers: They synthesize actin in the cytoskeleton
They degrade actin in the cytoskeleton
They store actin in the cytoskeleton

segments.title: Phospholipase C Signaling Pathway
segments.text: The **phospholipase C signaling pathway** is one of the three main pathways for transmitting signals within cells. This pathway is activated by **G-protein-coupled receptors**, which activate the **phospholipase C** enzyme via **heterotrimeric G proteins**. Phospholipase C then converts the phospholipid **PIP2** into two second messengers, **IP3** and **diacylglycerol (DAG)**. IP3 stimulates the release of calcium from the endoplasmic reticulum by binding to IP3 receptor-dependent calcium channels, while DAG remains in the membrane and activates **protein kinase C (PKC)**.

segments.title: Phospholipase C and the Plasma Membrane
segments.text: Phospholipase C is an **enzyme** that induces significant changes in the plasma membrane and **creates two second messengers**, namely **inositol trisphosphate (IP3)** and **diacylglycerol (DAG)**.

segments.question: What role does phospholipase C play in the plasma membrane?

answers.correct_answer: It creates two second messengers
wrong_answers: It destroys a second messenger
It produces one second messenger
It hides two second messengers

segments.title: G-Protein-Coupled Receptors
segments.text: **G-protein-coupled receptors** are cell surface molecules that transmit signals from outside the cell to the inside by activating **enzymes** such as phospholipase C. When these receptors receive a signal, they can activate **phospholipase C**, leading to a cascade of signal transduction within the cell.

segments.question: What is the role of G-protein-coupled receptors in relation to phospholipase C?

answers.correct_answer: They activate phospholipase C
wrong_answers: They inhibit phospholipase C
They degrade phospholipase C
They produce phospholipase C

segments.title: PIP2 Conversion by Phospholipase C
segments.text: Phospholipase C is responsible for converting **PIP2** (phosphatidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate), a phospholipid located in the plasma membrane, into two major secondary messengers: **IP3** (inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate) and **diacylglycerol (DAG)**.

segments.question: What are the products of PIP2 conversion by phospholipase C?

answers.correct_answer: IP3 and diacylglycerol (DAG)
wrong_answers: IP2 and triacylglycerol (TAG)
IP4 and monoglycerol (MG)
IP5 and diglycerol (DG)

segments.title: Inositol Trisphosphate (IP3)
segments.text: Inositol trisphosphate, or IP3, is a **signaling molecule** and **not a protein** that is produced by the activity of the enzyme phospholipase C. IP3 plays a crucial role in calcium signal transduction by diffusing through the cytoplasm and binding to **IP3 receptors** in the **endoplasmic reticulum (ER)**, leading to the **release of calcium ions** in the cell.

segments.question: What is the function of IP3 in the cell?

answers.correct_answer: It binds to calcium channels in the ER
wrong_answers: It binds to phospholipase C
It binds to diacylglycerol (DAG)
It binds to G-protein-coupled receptors

segments.title: Diacylglycerol (DAG)
segments.text: Diacylglycerol, or DAG, is another **signaling molecule** produced by the action of phospholipase C. Unlike IP3, DAG remains in the **plasma membrane** where it plays a role in activating **protein kinase C (PKC)**, an enzyme involved in various cellular functions.

segments.question: What is the function of DAG in the cell?

answers.correct_answer: It activates protein kinase C (PKC)
wrong_answers: It activates phospholipase C
It activates IP3
It activates G-protein-coupled receptors

segments.title: Phospholipase C Pathway
segments.text: In summary, the **phospholipase C pathway** is one of the three main signal transduction pathways involved in transmitting signals within cells. This pathway is activated by **G-protein-coupled receptors**, leading to the activation of the enzyme phospholipase C. Once activated, phospholipase C converts the membrane phospholipid PIP2 into two secondary messengers: **inositol trisphosphate (IP3)** and **diacylglycerol (DAG)**. IP3 induces the release of calcium ions from the endoplasmic reticulum, while DAG remains active in the membrane and activates **protein kinase C (PKC)**.

segments.question: Briefly describe the steps in the phospholipase C pathway.
segments.answer: Phospholipase C is activated by G-protein-coupled receptors (1 point) and converts PIP2 into IP3 (1 point), which induces calcium release (1 point), and DAG (1 point), which activates PKC (1 point).

segments.title: Isoforms of Phospholipase C
segments.text: There are different **isoforms of phospholipase C**, each activated by different types of receptors. For example, **PLC-beta 1** is activated by **G-protein-coupled receptors**, while **PLC-gamma 2** is activated by **receptor tyrosine kinases**. These isoforms enable cells to respond to various signals.

segments.question: What are two isoforms of phospholipase C?

answers.correct_answer: PLC-beta 1 and PLC-gamma 2
wrong_answers: PLC-alpha and PLC-delta
PLC-beta 1 and PLC-zeta
PLC-omega and PLC-gamma 2

segments.title: PLC-beta 1 and G-Protein-Coupled Receptors
segments.text: The isoform **PLC-beta 1** is activated by **G-protein-coupled receptors**. Activation of these receptors by external signals leads to the activation of PLC-beta 1 and subsequent signal transduction processes.

segments.question: By which type of receptor is PLC-beta 1 activated?

answers.correct_answer: G-protein-coupled receptors
wrong_answers: Receptor tyrosine kinases
Ion channels
Enzymatic receptors

segments.title: PLC-gamma 2 and Receptor Tyrosine Kinases
segments.text: **PLC-gamma 2** is specifically **activated by receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs)**. When an RTK binds a ligand, it undergoes a conformational change that stimulates **kinase activity**, ultimately leading to the activation of PLC-gamma 2.

segments.question: How is PLC-gamma 2 activated?

answers.correct_answer: By receptor tyrosine kinases
wrong_answers: By G-protein-coupled receptors
By ion channels
By enzymatic receptors

segments.question: What are the isoforms of phospholipase C and how do they differ in activation?
segments.answer: The isoforms of phospholipase C are PLC-beta 1 and PLC-gamma 2 (1 point). PLC-beta 1 is activated by G-protein-coupled receptors (1 point), while PLC-gamma 2 is activated by receptor tyrosine kinases (1 point).

segments.title: Biosensors in Signal Transduction
segments.text: In the study of signal transduction, **biosensors** are used to **detect the activity** of specific enzymes like phospholipase C. A biosensor consists of a **protein domain** that binds to a specific **signaling molecule**, coupled with a **fluorescent protein (GFP)**. This allows the location of the signaling molecule to be visualized under a microscope. Researchers can track the presence and **disappearance of signaling molecules** like **PIP2**, providing insight into the progression of signal transduction processes within the cell.

segments.question: What is the function of biosensors in signal transduction?

answers.correct_answer: They detect activity of specific enzymes
wrong_answers: They produce specific signaling molecules
They record the temperature of the cell
They hide specific signaling molecules

segments.title: Calcium as a Signaling Molecule
segments.text: Calcium ions (**Ca2+**) are extremely important signaling molecules in cellular processes. They can affect proteins in the cell by **causing conformational changes** due to altering the charge of a protein. Therefore, the **calcium concentration** in the cell is **strictly regulated**.

segments.question: What is the effect of calcium ions on proteins in the cell?

answers.correct_answer: They cause conformational changes
wrong_answers: They increase the temperature of the cell
They lower the pH of the cell
They cause protein degradation

segments.title: Regulation of Calcium Concentration
segments.text: The concentration of calcium outside the cell is about 10,000 times higher than in the cytoplasm. This is important for the proper functioning of enzymes in the cell. The concentration of calcium in the cytoplasm is kept as low as possible by **active transport** through **calcium channels** and **pumps**. These are responsible for transporting calcium ions in and out of the cell and to the ER or mitochondria.

segments.question: How is the calcium concentration in the cell regulated?

answers.correct_answer: By active transport via calcium channels and pumps
wrong_answers: By passive transport via calcium channels and pumps
By active transport via sodium-calcium channels and pumps
By passive transport via sodium-calcium channels and pumps

segments.title: Calcium Signaling in Muscle Cells
segments.text: In muscle cells, calcium signaling is triggered by an **action potential** or a specific **ligand**, such as acetylcholine. This leads to the **release of calcium ions** in the cell, which then causes **contraction** of myosin fibrils in the muscle cell.

segments.question: What triggers contraction of myosin fibrils in the muscle cell?

answers.correct_answer: An action potential or a specific ligand that induces calcium ion release
wrong_answers: A specific ligand that induces calcium ion uptake
An action potential that induces calcium ion synthesis
An action potential or a specific ligand that induces calcium ion degradation

segments.title: Ryanodine Receptor Abnormalities
segments.text: The ryanodine receptor is responsible for the release of calcium in the muscle cell. A leaky ryanodine receptor can lead to **calcium overload** in the cell, which can result in **paralysis**. On the other hand, an overly responsive ryanodine receptor can lead to **uncontrollable calcium release**, which can cause **muscle cramps**.

segments.question: What are the consequences of a leaky ryanodine receptor and an overly responsive ryanodine receptor?
segments.answer: A leaky ryanodine receptor can lead to **paralysis** (1 point), while an overly responsive ryanodine receptor can lead to **muscle cramps** (1 point).

segments.title: Calcium Waves in the Cell
segments.text: In cells, **calcium waves** can arise from the **release of calcium ions** from intracellular stores such as the endoplasmic reticulum. These waves can spread through the cell and cause a **cascade of calcium signals**. A small amount of calcium triggers a **positive feedback** cycle leading to a larger calcium wave, while a large amount of calcium triggers a **negative feedback** cycle, closing the channels and stopping the wave.

segments.question: How does calcium concentration affect the formation of calcium waves in the cell?

answers.correct_answer: A small amount of calcium triggers a positive feedback cycle leading to a larger calcium wave, while a large amount of calcium closes the channels and stops the wave
wrong_answers: A small amount of calcium triggers a negative feedback cycle leading to a smaller calcium wave, while a large amount of calcium opens the channels and strengthens the wave
A small amount of calcium triggers a positive feedback cycle leading to a smaller calcium wave, while a large amount of calcium opens the channels and strengthens the wave

segments.title: Vasopressin and Calcium Signaling
segments.text: Vasopressin is a hormone that affects **calcium signaling** in cells. It regulates calcium signaling by varying the **frequency of calcium release** in the cells. If vasopressin increases calcium release, there will be **more calcium spikes** in the cell. Note that the height of the spikes does not change, only the frequency.

segments.question: How does vasopressin affect calcium signaling?

answers.correct_answer: It regulates the frequency of calcium release
wrong_answers: It increases the calcium concentration
It decreases the calcium concentration
It increases the frequency of calcium uptake

segments.title: Calmodulin and Calmodulin-Dependent Protein Kinase
segments.text: **Calmodulin** (CaM) is a calcium-binding protein that, when it binds calcium ions, is able to activate other proteins such as **calmodulin-dependent protein kinase** (CaMK) by altering their shape.

segments.question: What does calmodulin do?

answers.correct_answer: It activates calmodulin-dependent protein kinase
wrong_answers: It inactivates calmodulin-dependent protein kinase
It degrades calmodulin-dependent protein kinase
It transports calmodulin-dependent protein kinase

segments.title: CaMKII Activation
segments.text: **After dissociation of calcium ions, CaMKII remains active** and can phosphorylate other proteins. This process is important for regulating various cellular processes and cognitive functions such as learning and memory.

segments.question: What happens after dissociation of calcium ions from CaMKII?

answers.correct_answer: It remains active and can phosphorylate other proteins
wrong_answers: It becomes inactive and can no longer phosphorylate other proteins
It degrades and can no longer phosphorylate other proteins
It undergoes a conformational change and can no longer phosphorylate other proteins

segments.title: Calcium and Cell Death
segments.text: **Too much calcium in the cell** can lead to **cell death**, a process known as **apoptosis**. This occurs because excessive calcium concentrations can damage various cellular structures, including mitochondria and enzymes, ultimately leading to cell death.

segments.question: What is the consequence of too much calcium in the cell?

answers.correct_answer: Cell death
wrong_answers: Cell division
Cell growth
Cell proliferation

segments.title: Convergent Signaling
segments.text: Convergent signaling is a process where **different signals** received by the cell, through different pathways, converge in the **nucleus**. This allows the cell to produce a **coordinated response** to multiple signals simultaneously, often resulting in adjustments to gene expression and other important cellular activities.

segments.question: What is convergent signaling?

answers.correct_answer: Different signals received by the cell, through different pathways, converge in the nucleus
wrong_answers: Different signals received by the cell, through the same pathway, converge in the nucleus
The same type of signals received by the cell, through different pathways, converge in the cell membrane
The same type of signals received by the cell, through the same pathway, converge in the cell membrane

segments.title: Enzyme-Linked Receptors
segments.text: Enzyme-linked receptors are a class of proteins in the cell membrane that a **signaling molecule**, such as a hormone or growth factor, can bind to. This can lead to **phosphorylation** of the receptor, making it active and initiating a **signal transduction pathway**.

segments.question: What are enzyme-linked receptors and how do they play a role in cell communication?

answers.correct_answer: Proteins in the cell membrane that undergo phosphorylation and activate a signal transduction pathway
wrong_answers: Proteins in the nucleus that undergo phosphorylation and activate a signal transduction pathway
Proteins in the cell membrane that undergo degradation and activate a signal transduction pathway
Proteins in the nucleus that undergo degradation and activate a signal transduction pathway

segments.title: Dimerization
segments.text: Dimerization is a process where two proteins bind together to form a **dimer**. There are two types of dimers: **homodimers**, consisting of two identical protein monomers, and **heterodimers**, consisting of two different protein monomers. Phosphorylation, the addition of a phosphate group, is often required to **activate** these receptors, after which dimerization occurs.

segments.question: What is dimerization and how is it related to receptor activation?
segments.answer: Dimerization is the binding of two proteins to form a dimer (1 point), and it can lead to receptor activation through phosphorylation (1 point).

segments.title: Protein Kinase
segments.text: Protein kinase activity refers to the function of enzymes that phosphorylate other proteins by adding a phosphate group. **Tyrosine kinases** are a specific group of protein kinases that phosphorylate **tyrosine residues** on proteins.

segments.question: What is the function of tyrosine kinases?

answers.correct_answer: They phosphorylate tyrosine residues on proteins
wrong_answers: They degrade tyrosine residues on proteins
They phosphorylate tyrosine on proteins
They hide tyrosine residues on proteins

segments.title: Activation of Receptor Tyrosine Kinases (RTK)
segments.text: Receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) are inactive in their monomer form and are activated by binding of a **signal protein**. This binding causes **dimerization** and **trans-autophosphorylation**. Once activated, RTKs provide phosphorylation sites for various intracellular signaling proteins, which further activate downstream signaling pathways.

segments.question: What initiates the activation of receptor tyrosine kinases?

answers.correct_answer: Binding of a signal protein leads to dimerization and autophosphorylation of RTKs
wrong_answers: Binding of a signal protein leads to degradation of RTKs
Dissociation of a signal protein leads to activation of RTKs
Binding of a signal protein reduces the phosphorylation activity of RTKs

segments.question: What is the function of trans-autophosphorylation in the activation of RTKs?

answers.correct_answer: It creates binding sites for signaling proteins and initiates downstream signal transduction
wrong_answers: It inactivates the kinase activity of RTKs and stops signal transduction
It prevents dimerization of RTKs and signal transduction
It shields the receptor from further signal protein binding

segments.title: Ras GTPase Activation by RTK
segments.text: The activation of the intracellular monomer Ras GTPase is initiated by **Receptor Tyrosine Kinase (RTK)** via **adaptor proteins** such as Grb2 and the guanine nucleotide exchange factor (GEF) called Sos. This process converts the transduction of extracellular signals into intracellular actions through **Ras GTPase**, which triggers the **MAPKinase signaling pathway**.

segments.question: Explain how the activation of RTK leads to signals reaching the nucleus?
segments.answer: The activation of RTK leads to the activation of Ras GTPase (1 point) via adaptor proteins (1 point), which activates the MAPKinase signaling pathway and sends signals to the nucleus (1 point).

segments.title: MAPKinase Pathway and Cancer
segments.text: The MAPKinase signaling pathway is essential for the **regulation of cell division**. Mutations in the Ras gene can lead to a form of Ras that is resistant to GTPase-activating proteins (GAPs), resulting in **continuously active Ras**. This causes **continuous activation of the MAPKinase pathway**, leading to **uncontrolled cell division** and potentially cancer.

segments.question: What can a mutation in the Ras gene lead to?

answers.correct_answer: Continuously active Ras and uncontrolled cell division
wrong_answers: Inactive Ras and uncontrolled cell division
Continuously active Ras and regulated cell division
Inactive Ras and regulated cell division

segments.title: MAPKinase Signaling Pathway
segments.text: The activation of the **MAPKinase signaling pathway** begins with a **growth factor** that activates Ras protein, which in turn activates **MAP kinase kinase kinase (Raf)**. Raf then activates **MAP kinase kinase (Mek)**, which activates **MAP kinase (Erk)**. These kinases **phosphorylate specific target proteins** in the cell, leading to **cell division** and other cellular responses.

segments.question: What are the steps in the MAPKinase signaling pathway?
segments.answer: Ras activates MAP kinase kinase kinase or Raf (1 point), Raf activates MAP kinase kinase or Mek (1 point), Mek activates MAP kinase or Erk (1 point), which leads to phosphorylation of target proteins in the cell (1 point).

segments.title: Scaffolding of Signaling Pathways
segments.text: Scaffolding proteins **organize proteins** such as MAPKinases in the MAPKinase signaling pathway. They act as a sort of **skeleton** on which the various proteins can bind and interact, thereby increasing the efficiency of signal transduction.

segments.question: What is the function of scaffolding proteins in signal transduction?

answers.correct_answer: They organize proteins in signaling pathways and increase the efficiency of signal transduction
wrong_answers: They degrade proteins in signaling pathways and decrease the efficiency of signal transduction
They transport proteins in signaling pathways and increase the efficiency of signal transduction
They isolate proteins in signaling pathways and decrease the efficiency of signal transduction

segments.title: PI3-Kinase Pathway
segments.text: The **PI3-kinase pathway** is another signal transduction mechanism that plays a role in cell survival. This pathway helps **inhibit apoptosis**, or programmed cell death, and **promotes cell survival**.

segments.question: What is the function of the PI3-kinase pathway?

answers.correct_answer: It inhibits apoptosis and promotes cell survival
wrong_answers: It promotes apoptosis and inhibits cell survival
It inhibits apoptosis and inhibits cell survival
It promotes apoptosis and promotes cell survival

segments.title: PI3-Kinase Pathway
segments.text: The PI3-Kinase pathway begins with the activation of a **receptor tyrosine kinase** (RTK), which then activates **PI3-kinase**. PI3-kinase **phosphorylates PI(4,5)P2 to PI(3,4,5)P3**. This leads to the activation of **Akt**, which **phosphorylates BAD** and releases an apoptosis-inhibiting protein.

segments.question: What are the steps in the PI3-kinase pathway?
segments.answer: RTK activates PI3-kinase (1 point), PI3-kinase phosphorylates PI(4,5)P2 to PI(3,4,5)P3 (1 point), which leads to the activation of Akt (1 point), which phosphorylates BAD (1 point) and releases an apoptosis-inhibiting protein (1 point).

segments.title: Direct Nuclear Signaling by JAK-STAT Pathway
segments.text: The JAK-STAT pathway is an example of **direct nuclear signaling** that occurs when **cytokine receptors** interact with their **ligands**. This pathway is **more efficient** compared to indirect signaling pathways like the MAPK pathway because it **directly activates transcription factors** that move to the nucleus to regulate gene expression. The JAK-STAT signaling pathway is particularly important in the immune response against viruses, such as in COVID-19.

segments.question: Why is the JAK-STAT pathway considered a form of direct nuclear signaling?

answers.correct_answer: Because receptor activation directly leads to activation of transcription factors
wrong_answers: Because it transmits signals through multiple intermediates before reaching the nucleus
Because it avoids the nucleus and only works in the cytosol to transduce signals
Because it uses G-proteins to transfer signals to the nucleus

segments.title: The Role of JAK and STAT Proteins
segments.text: In the JAK-STAT pathway, a cytokine receptor recognizes its cytokine, leading to dimerization and trans-autophosphorylation. This process activates JAK (Janus kinase), an enzyme linked to the receptor, which in turn phosphorylates STAT (signal transducers and activators of transcription) proteins. These STAT proteins then form homo- or heterodimers and move to the nucleus to regulate gene expression, resulting in various cellular responses such as cell division or the production of more cytokines.

segments.question: What happens to STAT proteins after they are phosphorylated by JAK proteins?

answers.correct_answer: They form dimers and move to the nucleus to regulate gene expression
wrong_answers: They remain in the cytoplasm to deactivate the JAK protein
They are secreted from the cell to function as cytokines
They bind to the cell membrane to serve as receptors

segments.title: Overview of Signal Transduction Pathways
segments.text: This image summarizes the main mechanisms by which cells interpret and convert external signals into functional responses. Two primary pathways are highlighted: the G-protein coupled receptor pathway (GPCR) and the receptor tyrosine kinase (RTK) pathway. These pathways use second messengers to transmit signals, which in turn activate a series of kinases. This activation cascade influences gene expression and induces a variety of cellular responses and behaviors.

segments.question: Give an example of a signal transduction pathway where the four main components: receptor, enzyme, second messenger(s), and kinase(s) are clearly present.
segments.answer: The answer should include a specific pathway (1 point), such as the G-protein coupled receptor pathway (GPCR). Name the receptor, such as a GPCR (1 point), the enzyme, such as phospholipase C (1 point), the second messenger, such as IP3 (1 point), and the kinase, such as protein kinase C (1 point).
